text: so I'm very lucky I actually experienced
failure very early in my life when I
started my first business as a teen I
enjoyed too much success too early I got
the opportunity to see all the things
that could go wrong or at least a good
number of them everything from product
failure to go to market failure to
financing failure to the challenges of
having for example a multinational
business and that is when I began to
learn stuff most entrepreneurs for
example think that if they understand
the full extent of what it takes from a
textbook standpoint to build a business
plan and hire a team and go after
marketplace that they're set up for
success in reality the number one thing
underneath that is actually what about
people so the challenge is to connect
the practical understanding of what it
is that needs to be done with the
reality of the people that need to do it
and enabling those people to go after
the constantly evolving and changing
opportunity in front of you and that's
what i learned from failure i learned
that if you can do that in a way that
enables people to be their best and to
address those opportunities as they
unfold as things change you can build an
unstoppable business most times what I'm
doing is trying to help students
actually understand what they can do
what's possible in their mind and help
them free in their own talents the kinds
of skills and experiences that will help
them build build great companies or
learn great things and I think the most
important thing I want students to try
to do is to have their own moment of
truth where they can understand what
their potential is and figure out how
they can use their own knowledge and
skills to gain experiences that are
authentic to them and help them build on
their own strengths and weaknesses
you
